lexUnit.name: shoal.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a large group or crowd

sentence.text: The principal town in this area is Ullapool , founded by the British Fisheries Society towards the end of the eighteenth century to exploit the shoals of herring that used to arrive each July .
In early April the excitement built up as the first shoals of mackerel were expected .
What you must beware of , however , is using all your bait on a massive shoal of small barbel .
On the other hand , a shoal of about 50 or 60 Spotted Rasbora , kept in a 4′ × 1′ tank , can be an extremely interesting exhibit in its own right .
Q I have often admired large shoals of Yellow Tangs , but people seem to be divided as to whether this is possible to achieve in the hole aquarium .
In the past week , John McLaughlin 's ` Barracuda " , captained by Des Mills , fishing out of Culdaff , Donegal , found large shoals of pollack , coalfish , ling and codling .
A small shoal of big bream may patrol a beat no wider than five yards .
More often than not a shoal of big bream , particularly a small shoal of very big bream , does not remain in a swim for long .
I will be keeping them in a 36″ × 12″ × 15″ tank with small shoal of Serpae Tetras and a Plec .
Bream have strong predatory instincts ( more of this later ) and it would not be safe for bream of only 2 or 3 inches to join a shoal of bigger bream .
I have watched a shoal of bream in shallow water for many hours .
That is , you can have a shoal of bream of one size at or near the bottom of a water , and a shoal of bigger or smaller bream above them .
When I have a shoal of feeding bream in the swim I can not rest easy .
A shoal of fish jumps out of the sea , a sight to quicken the heart as Tor says this often happens when the fish are being chased by orca .
A shoal of stout brown fish swam round and round in circles in a ghostly saraband before making their way to the entrance to the stream .
The next time you are along the river and you spot a shoal of chub , or an individual fish , see how close you can get VVI before they , or it , take fright .
As a shoal of some other kind of fish swims past , the predatory trumpet fish moves into their midst and progresses with them as they make their way around the coral gardens .

Instead it sails slowly through the water on flapping wings , sometimes as much as 7 metres across , its immense slot-like mouth wide open , gathering by filtration the floating shoals of crustaceans and small fish .
When they discover a shoal of smaller fish , they will harry them on all sides , driving them into such a dense concentration that the technique has been called ` meat-balling " .
